dataStructures.question: What is the time complexity of accessing an element in an array by index?
dataStructures.explanation: Array access by index is O(1) because it directly computes the memory location.

dataStructures.question: Which data structure follows Last In First Out (LIFO) principle?
dataStructures.explanation: Stack follows LIFO principle - the last element added is the first one to be removed.

dataStructures.question: What is the maximum number of children a binary tree node can have?
dataStructures.explanation: A binary tree node can have at most 2 children by definition.

dataStructures.question: Which of the following is NOT a linear data structure?
dataStructures.explanation: Tree is a non-linear data structure, while Array, Linked List, and Stack are linear.

dataStructures.question: What does FIFO stand for in data structures?
dataStructures.explanation: FIFO stands for First In First Out, which is the principle followed by queues.

dataStructures.question: What is the worst-case time complexity of quicksort?
dataStructures.explanation: Quicksort has O(n²) worst-case time complexity when the pivot is chosen poorly.

dataStructures.question: In a binary search tree, which traversal gives elements in sorted order?
dataStructures.explanation: In-order traversal of a BST gives elements in sorted (ascending) order.

dataStructures.question: What is the space complexity of a linked list with n elements?
dataStructures.explanation: A linked list requires O(n) space to store n elements.

dataStructures.question: Which data structure is used for implementing recursion?
dataStructures.explanation: Stack is used to implement recursion as it stores function call information.

dataStructures.question: What is the height of a balanced binary tree with n nodes?
dataStructures.explanation: The height of a balanced binary tree is O(log n).

dataStructures.question: What is the amortized time complexity of inserting an element into a dynamic array?
dataStructures.explanation: Dynamic arrays have amortized O(1) time complexity for insertions due to occasional resizing.

dataStructures.question: In a red-black tree, what is the maximum height of a tree with n nodes?
dataStructures.explanation: Red-black trees have a maximum height of 2 log(n+1).

dataStructures.question: What is the time complexity of finding the median in a max-heap?
dataStructures.explanation: Finding median in a heap requires O(n) time as we need to access all elements.

dataStructures.question: Which of the following data structures uses hashing?
dataStructures.explanation: Hash tables use hashing to map keys to values for efficient lookups.

dataStructures.question: What is the best case time complexity of bubble sort?
dataStructures.explanation: Bubble sort has O(n) best case time complexity when the array is already sorted.

dataStructures.question: Which data structure is used in breadth-first search?
dataStructures.explanation: BFS uses a queue to keep track of nodes to visit next.

dataStructures.question: What is the space complexity of a graph represented using adjacency matrix?
dataStructures.explanation: Adjacency matrix representation uses O(V²) space where V is the number of vertices.

dataStructures.question: Which sorting algorithm is stable?
dataStructures.explanation: Merge sort is a stable sorting algorithm that maintains the relative order of equal elements.

dataStructures.question: What is the purpose of a sentinel node in linked lists?
dataStructures.explanation: Sentinel nodes simplify boundary conditions by eliminating special cases for empty lists or end of list.

dataStructures.question: Which data structure is used for implementing LRU cache?
dataStructures.explanation: LRU cache is typically implemented using a combination of Hash Map for O(1) access and Doubly Linked List for O(1) updates.

networking.question: What does TCP stand for?
networking.explanation: TCP stands for Transmission Control Protocol, a connection-oriented protocol.

networking.question: Which layer of the OSI model is responsible for routing?
networking.explanation: The Network layer (Layer 3) is responsible for routing packets from source to destination.

networking.question: What is the purpose of ARP in networking?
options: Address Resolution Protocol - maps IP to MAC
networking.explanation: ARP (Address Resolution Protocol) maps IP addresses to MAC addresses in a local network.

networking.question: Which protocol is used for email transmission?
networking.explanation: SMTP (Simple Mail Transfer Protocol) is used for sending emails.

networking.question: What is the default port number for HTTP?
networking.explanation: HTTP uses port 80 by default for web traffic.

networking.question: Which device operates at the Data Link layer of the OSI model?
networking.explanation: Switches operate at the Data Link layer and use MAC addresses for forwarding.

networking.question: What does DNS stand for?
networking.explanation: DNS (Domain Name System) translates domain names to IP addresses.

networking.question: Which protocol provides secure communication over the internet?
networking.explanation: HTTPS (HTTP Secure) uses SSL/TLS encryption for secure communication.

networking.question: What is the maximum data rate of Ethernet?
networking.explanation: Modern Ethernet can support up to 10 Gbps and higher speeds.

networking.question: Which IP address class is used for multicasting?
networking.explanation: Class D IP addresses (224.0.0.0 to 239.255.255.255) are reserved for multicasting.

networking.question: What is the purpose of subnetting?
options: To divide a large network into smaller subnets
networking.explanation: Subnetting divides a large network into smaller, more manageable subnets.

networking.question: Which protocol is used for file transfer?
networking.explanation: FTP (File Transfer Protocol) is used for transferring files between computers.

networking.question: What is the size of an IPv4 address?
networking.explanation: IPv4 addresses are 32 bits long, providing about 4.3 billion unique addresses.

networking.question: Which device forwards data packets between different networks?
networking.explanation: Routers forward data packets between different networks based on IP addresses.

networking.question: What does NAT stand for?
networking.explanation: NAT (Network Address Translation) translates private IP addresses to public IP addresses.

networking.question: Which protocol is used for remote login?
networking.explanation: Telnet is used for remote terminal connections and command execution.

networking.question: What is the purpose of a firewall?
networking.explanation: Firewalls block unauthorized access and protect networks from security threats.

networking.question: Which wireless standard provides the fastest speed?
networking.explanation: 802.11ac (Wi-Fi 5) provides faster speeds compared to earlier standards.

networking.question: What is the purpose of DHCP?
networking.explanation: DHCP (Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol) automatically assigns IP addresses to devices.

networking.question: Which protocol is connection-oriented?
networking.explanation: TCP is a connection-oriented protocol that establishes a connection before data transfer.

operatingSystems.question: What is the main function of an operating system?
operatingSystems.explanation: The main function of an OS is to manage hardware resources and provide services to applications.

operatingSystems.question: Which scheduling algorithm can lead to starvation?
operatingSystems.explanation: Priority scheduling can lead to starvation if high priority processes keep arriving.

operatingSystems.question: What is thrashing in operating systems?
operatingSystems.explanation: Thrashing occurs when excessive paging causes the system to spend more time swapping than executing.

operatingSystems.question: Which of the following is NOT a process state?
operatingSystems.explanation: Terminated is not a standard process state. The main states are New, Ready, Running, Waiting, and Terminated.

operatingSystems.question: What is virtual memory?
operatingSystems.explanation: Virtual memory uses secondary storage (hard disk) to extend physical RAM capacity.

operatingSystems.question: Which algorithm is used for deadlock avoidance?
operatingSystems.explanation: Banker's Algorithm is used for deadlock avoidance by checking resource allocation safety.

operatingSystems.question: What is a semaphore used for?
operatingSystems.explanation: Semaphores are used for process synchronization and preventing race conditions.

operatingSystems.question: Which scheduling algorithm is preemptive?
operatingSystems.explanation: Round Robin is a preemptive scheduling algorithm that uses time quantum.

operatingSystems.question: What is the purpose of the kernel?
options: Core part that manages system resources
operatingSystems.explanation: The kernel is the core part of the OS that manages system resources and hardware.

operatingSystems.question: Which of the following is NOT a type of operating system?
operatingSystems.explanation: Virtual OS is not a standard type. The main types are Batch, Time-sharing, Real-time, and Distributed.

operatingSystems.question: What is a critical section?
options: Part of code that must be executed atomically
operatingSystems.explanation: Critical section is a part of code that must be executed atomically to avoid race conditions.

operatingSystems.question: Which memory management technique uses paging?
operatingSystems.explanation: Paging is a non-contiguous memory allocation technique that divides memory into fixed-size pages.

operatingSystems.question: What is the purpose of the page table?
options: Map virtual addresses to physical addresses
operatingSystems.explanation: Page table maps virtual memory addresses to physical memory addresses.

operatingSystems.question: Which of the following can cause a deadlock?
operatingSystems.explanation: Deadlock requires four conditions: mutual exclusion, hold and wait, no preemption, and circular wait.

operatingSystems.question: What is the difference between multiprogramming and multiprocessing?
options: Multiprogramming uses multiple CPUs, multiprocessing uses single CPU
Multiprogramming uses single CPU, multiprocessing uses multiple CPUs
operatingSystems.explanation: Multiprogramming runs multiple programs on a single CPU, while multiprocessing uses multiple CPUs.

operatingSystems.question: Which file system is used in Windows?
operatingSystems.explanation: NTFS (New Technology File System) is the primary file system used in Windows.

operatingSystems.question: What is the purpose of the swap space?
operatingSystems.explanation: Swap space (swap file/page file) is used to extend virtual memory capacity.

operatingSystems.question: Which scheduling algorithm gives the minimum average waiting time?
operatingSystems.explanation: SJF (Shortest Job First) gives the minimum average waiting time for processes.

operatingSystems.question: What is the purpose of the system call?
operatingSystems.explanation: System calls allow user programs to request services from the operating system.

operatingSystems.question: Which of the following is a volatile memory?
operatingSystems.explanation: RAM (Random Access Memory) is volatile memory that loses data when power is turned off.
